Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1

 Hello,

I'm currently trying to reproduce the results in
http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/publications/2009/risi.gecco09.html and finding out
if a NEAT algorithm is necessary to obtain theses results. Right now, I
manage without too many problems to get behaviors changing depending on the
trial / deploy.

 Though, the novelty keeps trying new behaviors based upon crashing / not
crashing or getting one reward or not getting it, and returning or not
returning to the origin (no reward). This fills up the archive quite fast
without any actual "learning" appearing (the best scores show 60% to 70% of
all high reward reached without any clear "learning" pattern).

I would like to know if some code is provided online for this experiment, or
if you could send me the code used in this experiment, if only to try to see
which parameters are different in the two of them, so that I can try to
pinpoint the differences.

Right now, the differences I can see are :
- simple network evolution algorithm vs NEAT mechanisms
- possible difference in the way of counting for novelty score : I am using
a bitset of size 4*nb_deploy*nb_trials with each bit standing for : a crash,
a high reward, a low reward, returning to the starting point wit the reward.
I do a hamming distance between behaviors to get my novelty score. But, it
seems to be the same mechanisms as in the paper
- generation based algorithm while the paper uses a a steady state approach
in which only one individual is generated at each generation

Cheers.

Paul Tonelli

--001517478cceb673480479eabd43
